body: I don't believe I ever said that threats of suicide shouldn't be taken seriously. I agree with the opposite. Even if it is a call for help, any normal person would feel an obligation to take action. I had a friend in high school who, before I met him, "attempted" commit suicide by over dosing. In the back of my mind I always wondered why he chose such an unreliable method. Of course I never said that to him out of common  decency but I was illegitimately curious for the reasons behind it. I feel like a struck a bit of a nerve with some people here but that was a natural side affect of curiosity.

name: t1_cb3he94
author: novagenesis
body:
Not just witnesses.  The concrete-caused head wound is a certainty.  Ballistics assure 2-12" range, and suggest strongly that the shot happened while Martin was on top of Zimmerman.  When the witness matches the story matches the evidence, it's usually what we call "open and shut".

Honestly, I wish I knew what the prosecution was thinking when they pressed charges at all.  What did they know that they weren't allowed to present, or what did they think they knew that wasn't resolved in discovery?

name: t1_cbsfdsh
author: [deleted]
body:
1.  The worst thing that Voldemort could do to harry is kill him.  A dementor can eat his soul.  So not only is he a mindless automaton until his body gives out, but he can't come back as a ghost, and he can't "go on" and be with his parents.  Dementors are one of the scariest enemies, not just in HP, but in all of fiction.  *Machin Shin* from the Wheel of Time is about the only thing scarier.

2.  Prisoner of Azkaban sets up Sirius's storyline, and finally gives Harry a family - not that Mr. and Mrs. Weasley weren't fantastic surrogate parents, but in the books, a godfather/godkid relationship is portrayed to be 99% as important as that between biological parents and their kids.

3.  Buckbeak is a badass.

4.  Excellent quidditch action.

name: t1_cbsfzmb
author: IbrahimT13
body:
The third book is absent of danger? What about the Dementors that Harry regularly encounters, nearly dying most of the time? While Sirius Black ends up being an ally, for the first part of the book, there definitely was a very real fear of the idea of Sirius Black. 

PoA has a lot of the same elements (such as how developed the world is and the humour, etc.) as the first two books, but is a lot darker in a sense. It builds up an inevitably direct clash between good and evil. You mention that the best books are ones like the Chamber of Secrets, but Voldemort didn't even really come into play until the end; the characters were more worried about the Basilisk (though they didn't know it was, in fact, a Basilisk). In PoA, there is supposed to be someone directly out to get Harry, which doesn't go for the first two. In my opinion, that's more of a danger.

Regarding angst: books like The Goblet of Fire and The Order of the Phoenix are way, way more angsty. In fact, off the top of my head, all that I can really think about that qualifies as angst in PoA is when Harry contemplates going after Sirius Black (which isn't even necessarily teenage angst, seeing as it could happen to anyone), and Ron and Hermione's issues with each other. As a matter of fact, I think that one of the better parts of PoA is that develops characters in a much better way than the first two books, while not laying it on too much. The characters grow way more in this book than the first two, and there are way more moral issues and such.

And yet, even though there's character development and such, one thing I really like about PoA is that it still retains similar flavour and charm from the first two books. However, it's the only year where disasters and other things don't ruin the year for the students, even though dark events are still unfolding. Things like the Boggart lesson and the Quidditch final are enjoyable because nothing like that really happens in other books. In the first book, everything was new and shiny; in the second, there were people being attacked; in the fourth book, there was the Triwizard Tournament; in the fifth, there was Umbridge; in the sixth, the anti-Voldemort movement was started, and the the last book was barely at Hogwarts. PoA mixes the danger of the second with the world-building of the first in a good way. 

It's also a really good transition and set-up for the Voldemort-filled part of the series, and the ending isn't a perfect Hollywood ending like the first two. There are doubts and the real servant of Voldemort is on the loose at the end. It's less sweet. It's nice to have Harry save the day, win a million points for Gryffindor with his antics, and have his friends all cheer for him, but it's far more interesting to have an ending that leaves you with questions and doubts for the next book. Voldemort doesn't hurt Harry at the end, but his servant is off to resurrect him. 

Also, I don't know why you're merely dismissing the backstory and time travel aspects. The backstory was really interesting. The time travel was plain cool. It was icing on the cake, but at least it can help in avoiding last place. 

Finally, the third book is, in my opinion, one of the best to re-read. For more intense books like the last one, a lot of the intensity/drama/action/suspense is lost when you re-read it. The PoA is a good mix of mystery and other stuff, so it's better for re-reading. 

**TL;DR, PoA has more danger, better character development and world-building, a better ending and re-read value, and lots of other cool factors, including time travel.**

name: t1_cbt1zp5
author: wearing2raincoats
body:
Reading all of these answers has reminded me of all the legitimately awesome stuff in this book, and I thank every one of you, but I'll respond to this one to bring up my one remaining caveat.

It seems that the reason PoA is great is because it fleshes out the HP world a lot more drastically than the first two did, and brings out a lot of side stories that make the HP world so interesting. One example I just remembered is the Ministry being a much more real presence, which brought a maturity to a world that was mostly run by a just-kids mentality for two books. However, even though the distractions from Voldemort were much-needed and never boring, it feels like PoA was artificially set up as such. The later books (i.e. the much longer ones) had what I feel is a better balance of non-Voldy plot development and main storyline events. But in PoA, it feels like Rowling decided to dedicate an entire book to just fleshing out the world. It was obviously successful, but I think it stands out as something like a very interesting intermission for the series instead of a legitimate entry in the saga of Harry Potter, the Boy who Lived.

name: t1_ccik36d
author: ProjectD13X
body: Eh, that article didn't really say WHY it was good, just that it was good.  At the end he brings up some of the problems with the movie, but then just says "FUCK THAT THOUGH, THIS IS GREAT."

name: t1_ccip0by
author: [deleted]
body:
It is not necessary to have a complex character for a character study in feature film. The character only needs to be interesting. I think that Plainview is plenty interesting. There was some ambiguity in his character that keeps you intrigued. There is obviously something to his relationship with H.W. that goes beyond simple exploitation. Saving him from the oil well and the way he cradle him afterwards shows that there is some sort feelings there. Also how he greets H.W. on his return from the school again shows that something has developed between them. Also his interactions with Henry show that he wanted some sort of human relationship otherwise he would of just sent him away after their first meeting.

I didn't have any problem with the structure of the movie or the leaps in time. This is the first I've heard of anybody having issue with that as well. I don't know what else to say about that.

I don't think broader context was really necessary for the film and in fact think that the intense focus on Plainview was one of its strengths. I think broadening the focus would have meant that the film would have lost its tension.

I don't see Plainview killing Eli as puzzling. In fact I think it is really the only ending that would have made sense. What happens to somebody that is driven by success to sociopathic ends after they win that success? They turn on themselves and anybody around them. This is why it also showed Plainview pushing H.W. out of his life for good.

The fact that the pencils were regifted was sort of a huge insult, especially since they still had someone else's name on it. It showed that the person who gave it to me didn't put enough thought into the gift to even remove information that it was regifted, they just grabbed something and handed it over. It's the thoughtlessness in that instance that made it offensive. 

If you don't want to advertise regifting, you can say something like "when I saw this I thought of you" and to me, the thought is stated and overt. Just remember to take off all the gift tags first :D

name: t1_cf6qwoo
author: eye_patch_willy
body:
Fully endorsing /u/electricfistula's great answer, and adding on.  Season 8 never felt like a final season.  So many new characters were introduced, just to be killed off.  Dr. Vogel's character, while brilliantly played by Charlotte Rampling, made no fucking sense.  Her connection to Dexter and Harry is ludicrous.  At no point in the series was she even hinted at.  To me, it was clear that the writers never envisioned this aspect of Dexter's myth when they created the show and the character, it was purely forced into place for this one season.  
  
The other new characters also seemed to only be introduced to be killed so that the characters we've all come to know get to live (save Deb, who dies because of a one in a million blood clot- just so she and Dex can have one last conversation while she's in the hospital).  No other arc is closed.  Angel, Quinn, and Matthews are still in the dark about who Dexter really was.  This makes LaGuerta's death even more pointless than it already seemed.  Jamie still hasn't done anything important.  
  
Those things plus Dexter and Hannah turning into bumbling idiots as already pointed out turned the last season into a disaster.  The other HUGE GAPPING hole that was never addressed in either S7 or S8 was the scene in S5 where Deb walks in on Dexter and Lumen about to kill Jordan Chase (they can't see each other because of a opaque tarp) and Deb lets them go.  Suddenly Deb finds out Dexter is a serial killer and has this huge crisis of conscious.  In what universe does it make sense that the scene in the basement never comes up between the two of them???????????????

name: t1_cg676fl
author: w41twh4t
body:
I'm not one of those who think there were no bad episodes in the first 3 seasons so there are plenty of bad episodes there that are really no different from S4 eps. 

But try this, make a list of the top 10 episodes. What is the highest you'd have from S4? Off the top of my head from the first 3 seasons you have Paintball, the Bottle ep, the Xmas claymation, Halloween zombies, Paintball II, D&D, the video game ep, and the alternate universe ep. Nothing from S4 comes to mind.

Of course comedy is subjective but I don't think S4 has a single ep worthy of a top 10 and would be lucky to have one or two in the top 20. At the same time if we did a bottom 10 it wouldn't be all S4 or even half S4 so it isn't as bad as some make it. The difference is real however that S4 had no single brilliant 10/10 or even 9/10 episodes.

name: t1_ch30sac
author: [deleted]
body:
You should be allowed to expect other people not to rape you. It's pretty much as simple as that. He got wildly drunk under this perfectly reasonable expectation, and the fact that this expectation was not met is entirely the fault of the old flame. 

Furthermore, he tried to show the old flame that he was not interested: he went so far as to show her pictures of his fiancee. If anyone should have refrained from alcohol, it was the old flame, as perhaps she knew that were she to be drunk and find him compromised, she would have a difficult time resisting taken advantage. But that's all on her, not on him. 

One way to think about it is the example of people who wear clothes that can be called provocative. Even if this does increase the likelihood that they'll be raped (I don't know whether it does or not), they are not to blame in the least if they are raped. It's the same situation here: increasing the likelihood that you'll be raped does not make you at fault. Would you say someone walking around a dangerous area was to blame for being murdered?

name: t1_ch33462
author: [deleted]
body: Are you saying you would blame the woman as you are blaming the man?

name: t1_ch33u0t
author: [deleted]
body:
I'm saying he was in no physical state to be able to consent; therefore it was rape and he has no responsibility, hence the "conscious" clause in my other post.

Also, if we can't tell how passed out he is, the Mandy should have 100% of MAKING SURE he has the ability to consent, not do it anyway and hope for the best.

name: t1_ch36a9d
author: Mavericgamer
body: The problem here is that he definitely did not say "yes, have sex with me" under the definition of informed consent; if you aren't cognizant enough to remember what happened, you aren't cognizant enough to give consent. Even if he had said "yes" while blacked out, he didn't have the ability to consent. If you aren't in a state to know where you are and who with because you're that gone... you see what I'm getting at?

name: t1_ch3gnvh
author: sheep74
body:
essentially it boils down to this.

Both parties talk while at a reasonable level of sobriety. At this point it's clear that one of them wants to bang (A) and one doesn't (B). At this point it's unreasonable for B to assume there's any danger, they are in control of their own decisions, they have rejected flirtation and they are in safe and comfortable surroundings. They also aren't going to assume that A needs to hear a clear 'no i will not have sex with you tonight' in order to avoid sex. Do you say that to everyone you meet just in case they get confused and think you want it? No, consent needs to be enthusiastic. For A to have any defense, B would have at one point need to actively engage in the idea of banging which clearly didn't happen. 

Later B is so drunk that they black out. At this point, and even before, people are unable to consent to sex. Even if they say yes, it doesn't count because alcohol. At this point if anyone has sex with B it's pretty much rape (unless you get into the confusing situation where the other person was as drunk and both parties were fully involved in the act)

A is possibly also drunk, but clearly able to still move around. A friend, C, witnesses B pretty much passed out and unresponsive while A performs oral sex. It is clear that this is not a reciprocal session. 

At this point it's pretty clear that A is more sober than B. B even seems unable to drunkenly consent. A had already asserted their intentions, and B theirs. They conflicted yet A has ignored this.

Further evidence is that, while B wakes up unable to form words or thoughts, A is already up and driving. This indicates enough disparity between their drunkeness that A is entirely culpable for what happened.

Maybe if sober A wouldn't have done it. But do we excuse men who hit their wives only when drunk? Or people who murder under the influence of crazy drugs? No, A's state does not impact the fact they committed a crime.

name: t1_ch3j0r0
author: rocaterra
body:
He wouldn't be charged if nobody knew whether or not the girl was passed out.  Correct me if I'm wrong, but all we have to go by is his drunk friend saying he *looked* passed out.

Man definitely should get busted in that scenario.  We are aware she was passed out.  Here we are not.

name: t1_ch3kgyz
author: rocaterra
body:
I think I did, sorry.  

I appreciate that you acknowledge the ambiguity, and still bring it around to being out of his control.  

While I would blame myself if I was in that guy's position, it's not my place to fairly judge and thus I should give him the benefit of the doubt.  Even if I'm able to understand his situation better, I'm still not able to enough to do so fairly.  &#8710;

Lots of other great responses that brought me to this point, but I think this is the one that finished the job.

name: t1_ch3p1te
author: Mavericgamer
body:
There is a line between "drunk" and blackout, not conscious drunk. When you are so drunk that you can't stand, don't remember the next morning, and aren't even conscious half the time, active sex can't happen. If one party is that drunk, and sex still happened, it implies the other party was not.

In the situation you mentioned, you might be too drunk to safely operate a motor vehicle, but not too drunk to consent. If both parties were equally drunk, however, then they were both equally able to consent.

name: t1_chstnie
author: logimath
body: For better or for worse, America has an individualistic narrative. It is romantic to think that we cut our own trenches. This is not my view; I am my children's parent forever, and I will always have more experience. Why would I not continue to teach and try to guide as long as I can? This goes against the idea of the self-made american, which is a very influential theme in the American ideology. I can't even think of an influential American author that didn't explore individualism and the self-made *person*.

One example was in Season 2 when Sam told Dean to kill him if he went "dark side', because he didn't want to become something that would hurt Dean or anyone else. Another time was in Season 8, Sam wanted to do the Demon trials and Dean told him no. It wasn't until Sam successfully killed a Hellhound and Dean wanting to hunt then kill another one, that Sam was able to convince Dean to let him finish the trials. Little brothers get into trouble and big brothers get them out all the time.

Look mate, at 18 most people think they're fugly, here's a tip, no one pays as much attention to how you look as you. As a wide note my acne cleared up when I dropped sugar and wheat for three months. Try playing with your diet or even lifestyle to see what happens.

name: t1_cmcetow
author: davidmanheim
body:
It's entirely possible that Wilson believe himself to be in danger. That doesn't excuse anything,  nor should it have been relevant. The goal of police training and procedure is twofold;  to not place themselves in positions where they might need to fire to defend themselves,  and to help reduce the risk of incorrectly identifying some non dangerous situation as dangerous. 

If I punch you in the face,  I may have reason to worry that you may then hurt me; this is not justification for shooting you. Wilson screwed up. Maybe he screwed up honestly believing he was in danger,  but he put himself there,  against proper procedure,  then overreacted. That's not to say he didn't think he was in danger - but he had the responsibility not to screw up the way he did.

name: t1_cmcfjhb
author: Technologenesis
body:
I mean I had been under the impression that Wilson was pretty far back at the time of the shooting, so it seems like he did stay fairly far back. If he was rushed at, which as far as I'm aware is a perfectly reasonable possibility, shooting would have been the right thing to do despite the fact that he had tried to maintain a reasonably safe distance.

If you're talking about the altercation at the car, I don't think that's fair at all. An officer can't be expected to stay 50 feet away from absolutely everyone he confronts.

Actually though I see something here that might change my view.  What do you think the proper protocol was?  How should Wilson have handled the situation?  As far as I could see, Wilson was taking the most reasonable options available to him, or at least there's reason to believe he may well have been.  If I see something else that was more reasonable, though, I think I would change my view.

name: t1_cmcmrsu
author: z3r0shade

name: t1_cmculcq
author: Super_Duper_Mann
body: Hey OP - [this article](http://www.vox.com/2014/11/25/7281165/darren-wilsons-story-side) speaks to the reason you gave that delta. Very good analysis of Wilson's side of the story and comes to the same conclusion that you have. You might find it worth reading!

name: t1_cmcz2h1
author: theslowwonder
body:
I just read two full testimonies, one by Darren Wilson and one by Michael Brown's friend, who was with him at the time. It's hard to read either account without noting that Wilson did not make it clear to the men what was taking place before initiating the altercation. Wilson had yelled from his window for the two to stop walking in the street, and was upset when they didn't immediately change course. He reversed to them, tried to open his door, but it shut back on him because he didn't have room to open it. So, Wilson grabbed Brown by the neck from his window and started lecturing him, though no one is sure of their conversation, this is when the scuffle started.

This cop didn't use his speaker or lights or follow any normal police procedures to let these guys know what was going on. I don't dispute that Brown scared him at some point, but he approached this in a way that escalates situations, not defuses them as police are trained to do. Had Brown not died, it's more likely he would have received punishment for how poorly this situation was handled.

name: t1_cmde47f
author: Raborn
body: And assault justifies murder..... where? If he's afraid for his life, let him go seems like the correct response.

name: t1_cmdfadm
author: emotional_panda
body:
Admittedly the facism thing was just bullshit. But here are some points we can move along on. 

1)Cops are trained to subdue people. This is true, but they are also trained to be physically fit, courteous/professional, and competent in the law. However, most cops rarely get more than 6 months of training. Taking into account that 6 months of doing anything puts the average person at a skill level of just above novice, we have to know what their abilities are. Cops will not be able to stop an assailant without causing serious injury or death. Just like anyone else, they are entitled to kill if an assailant presents them with the intent to harm/kill them. Police do not magically have the ability to subdue criminals.

2)Killing someone is rarely the best option. But we hardly choose our circumstances, especially when our assailants force those circumstances on us. We have to recognize that police officers being attacked can not change circumstances simply because they have been trained. They are just like any other average person. And so they should be given the right to defend themselves just like any other average person.

3)If cops should/ought to be the type of people to be able to prevail over these kinds of circumstances then we need to either extend the rights of the average citizen as to make the service of police obsolete or we need to extensively reconstruct the way we train police officers. I think that in order to satisfy your standard of what an officer should be able to do, we need to train them to be on par with special military forces. The problem with that is that we give the government a paramilitary force in small towns. 
Imagine if you will: Police are trained to a standard such that they can physically subdue someone 100lbs heavier than them. Do we really want every police officer in our town to have that much power? Do we want government giving orders to such people? Police forces are already corrupt but now they have the physical power to act with impunity. I guess this is where my facism thing ties in.

In short, we either need to give more rights to citizens so that police are obsolete and we can avoid police brutality or we must train police to be on par with the military and risk giving government and police too much power.

name: t1_cmdtn63
author: emotional_panda
body: I think we have more common ground than we thought. Essentially, yes, cops are town guards with itchy trigger fingers. I don't think we'll ever see them trained to any standard of competence. We have to stop worrying about cops and start talking about giving citizens the rights to defend themselves. At least when citizens defend themselves they are held liable to the full extent of the law. In this way, we can create a culture where it is understood that assaulting someone has deep consequences but that defending your life also has some restrictions.

I don't agree with the law, but that is the law. name: t1_cpov03f
author: TuckerMcG
body:
First of all, Dale is a much better role model than John Redcorn. Redcorn is a womanizing, selfish, greedy (as evidenced by how he's willing to drop Luanne's Manger Babies from his VHS distribution company), and all around pompous person (he thinks his shitty death metal band is the greatest thing ever). He's also an extremely anger filled man, constantly discussing taking revenge on "the white man". 

Dale, albeit a little crazy and paranoid, is actually kind, caring, thoughtful and above all else, selfless (remember when he saved the Stick-Tec office by killing thousands of roaches with his bare hands? Or when he rushed to save Joseph from the alien overlords at the Marfa Lights? Or the countless times he's shown his devotion and love for his wife?). The only thing Dale really dislikes is Bill, for being so pathetic and disgusting, and Rusty Shackleford, for totally made up reasons. 

So it's much better for Joseph to grow up a little weird if it means he gets to learn good, quality values. The only thing he'd learn from John Redcorn is how to be a selfish asshole who fucks any woman he can in a vendetta against an entire race of people. 

We also see that Joseph thinks John Redcorn is a pretty weird dude in the Thanksgiving episode, so I'm pretty sure going to live with him would be pretty damaging to Joseph. Not to mention that John Redcorn doesn't know the first thing about parenting.   

Also, sure John Redcorn might be hurt that he doesn't get to raise Joseph, *but that's the price you pay when you stick your dick in another man's wife*. Seriously, fuck John Redcorn. I'm glad he has to silently suffer while watching Dale raise his kid. He's a piece of shit, so the resulting harm to him is negligible.

And as other people said, Hank typically stays out of people's personal business. Even if it's totally fucked up, he tries to keep personal details like sexual relations completely secret (he doesn't even like Luanne using the bathroom in his and Peggy's room). He would *never* broach the subject of intimate sexual relations with his friends - he avoids those conversations at all costs (watch the episode where Connie gets her first period for ample evidence of this aversion). 

He also sees how destructive divorce can be, thanks to Bill. Hank sort of sees the value in "ignorance is bliss" at least when it comes to Dale. Bill at least has a steady paying military job. Dale would be homeless trying to live off of Dale's Deadbug (we're constantly reminded that Nancy is the breadwinner, and we see in the episode where Nancy goes to work in Dallas that Dale cannot take care of himself). So it's actually better for Dale to not be privy to the true father of Joseph as well. 

If Hank told Dale, and Dale believed him (which is also a stretch), then it would ruin pretty much everyone's lives who are involved in it. Dale becomes homeless, Joseph is now a child of divorced parents who realizes at 13 that he's a different race than he thought, Nancy would have to deal with the publicity that would likely result from this, and John Redcorn's life as he knows it comes crashing down once he has legal guardianship over a child (no more banging sluts when he's gotta take Joseph to football practice).

name: t1_cqevg02
author: feedmesweat
body:
The finale of Breaking Bad was 3 episodes long. In *Ozymandias*, we got to see Walt's world come crashing down around him. In *Granite State*, he was sent to a sort of purgatory, forced to finally confront the awful things he had done, instead of continually running from them. 

*Felina* wasn't an example of Walt becoming an "Avenging Hero". Only in that episode did he fully understand the extent to which his actions had ruined so many lives. He was taking his biggest skill - solving problems - and applying it to the purpose of atoning for his sins, in whatever small way he could. 

As for the "I did it for me" speech: however thoroughly Walt had convinced himself that he was doing everything to provide for his family, the truth is it was fueled by greed, ambition, and a lifetime of feeling stifled and meek. It was entirely selfish of him to continue in the drug trade after the events of the first 3 episodes. That speech was the only time he was actually honest with Skyler - or anyone - about his motivations.

name: t1_cqzdpbc
author: shogi_x
body:
First off, let me state it's been a while since my last viewing, so forgive me if I mistake details.  That said-
This is true, which is why real world politicians tend to not make grand promises of what they will accomplish, but rather what they will fight for- with no guarantee of delivery.  Her campaign was run purely on hopes and dreams, and more than a few politicians have seen the end of their careers when they failed to deliver those.  Failure of this magnitude is a justifiable reason to seek a change in president, regardless of how realistic the goal is.
This is an illogical response, one born of emotion rather than reason.  Understandable, but not justifiable.  They are offering badly needed aid, that you arguably may not survive without.  It could be suicide to dismiss them, meeting them with violence could be costly, and trusting them explicitly would be unwise.  Therefore the rational solution is to accept their aid, but monitor them closely and limit their movement until you can be sure of their trustworthiness.  I believe that Adama satisfied these conditions in the initial standoff when they arrived.  Their interaction with the fleet was limited, and Galactica positioned itself with a lethal response ready at all times until their trust was earned by way of the testimony of trusted allies and deeds done by the Cylons.  Even then Adama was reluctant, but was pressed by circumstance to accept them.  Mind you, this is how they handled Athena when she returned with Helo.
Very true.  At that point, their government bore little resemblance to a democracy and looked much more like a dictatorship, though I would argue this was necessary given the fragility of the fleet and responsibilities of its admiral.  Despite it's deeply negative stigma and undemocratic nature, martial law is not without its merits when used responsibly.

Now here comes the part where I disagree with you- mutiny was not the answer.  I will admit that mutiny is a justifiable means in certain scenarios, but this was not one of them. 

* Firstly, Adama's actions were (mostly) neither unreasonable nor without their own justifications, which as I recall was communicated to the fleet.  His unofficial reign after Roslin's unofficial abdication was also very short before the mutiny, which was orchestrated by people with a long-standing grudge (Zarek and Gaeta).

* Secondly, the primary spark was the presence of the Cylons who made every effort to be valuable to the fleet and nonthreatening.  As I said above, violent opposition to their presence was irrational.

* Third, Adama and his loyalty had been proven multiple times at this point, having saved the fleet more times than anyone can count, and his judgement has proven sound throughout their years on the run.  The sudden change of opinion in the fleet was ignorant of this.  While it's not really reasonable to say he should never be doubted, it should have given far more pause than the colonists gave.

* Finally, mutiny was a potentially self-destructive action.  Given the precarious position the fleet was in, a mutiny could have resulted in unnecessary loss of life (it did), loss of critical ships/resources/infrastructure, permanent damage to the survivability of the fleet and, by extension, the human race.

**TL;DR**, Given the risks, Adama's track record, and irrational motivations, I find that while mutiny was not without cause, it was unjustified as a solution, especially above other options.

-edit- words, etc.

name: t1_cs8wghl
author: skunkardump
body:
I would say that Fedor was GOAT heavyweight in any promotion based on his legendary win streak, something I doubt anyone will ever come close to in UFC.  However I do think that not having to cut weight is something of an advantage at heavyweight.  Whether or not it's more of an advantage than size itself is debatable, but clearly most heavyweights don't bulk up to 265, and there are very few human beings that would have to cut down to 265 (unless they're fat obviously).  There seems to be diminishing returns on size once you get well over 200 lbs.  Ali wasn't that big himself, though he had a huge reach, much like Jon Jones, who many would have considered a favorite at heavyweight, even against the likes of Cain Velasquez.  It's extremely rare for fighters in other divisions to weigh in at less than a pound or two under the limit.  If UFC had a super heavyweight division I probably wouldn't give Lesnar as much credit.

Cain also has more losses in title fights, and what he may or may not do in the future is irrelevant.  Couture has more wins in title fights than Cain, especially if you consider his lhc reigns.  Would you consider Couture above Cain?

name: t1_cscanwg
author: dervidjerseph
body:
Let me expound a bit.  I think this question is a little bit more loaded than you thought.  If you're arguing that Healy's bad at his job, you won't find any argument here-but keep in mind who his colleagues are:

1)Caputo-masturbates to women after they come to him with issues.

2)Figueroa-embezzles money from the prison.

3) Luschak-conspires to sell heroin.

4) Bennett-gets an inmate pregnant.

5) Mendez-smuggles contraband, has sex with inmates, etc.

6) O'Neill and Bell - sex within Litchfield

Compared to all of these people, Healy looks like a saint.  Being bad at your job is relative, after all.

name: t1_cscg2p4
author: ihearthiking
body:
Soso overdosed on meds that she stole from the Dr's office- Healy sent her to the Dr, the Dr's incompetence is the reason a pile of unattended pills was left in a room where a prisoner could grab them if she wanted them.  

Having said that, I feel like they do a decent job with that character.  He is supposed to be helping inmates, but he has been there a long time, and people who are in positions like that have something similar to battle fatigue where they become less compassionate and more suspicious of games.  

I think that he realizes that he made some terrible moves in Season 1 & the beginning of Season 2, and is trying/ did try to help.  He had that Circle group with Penn, and he tries to help Red when he can.  

Like many people, he is actually a combination of decency and selfishness or pettiness.  

He may not be the best at his job, but he isn't the worst.  And in that system, sometimes the one who isn't selling drugs & having sex with inmates, etc, is the one who is "good" at his job, by comparison.  

Although, my vote for the one prison guard who seems to actually be good at his job would have to be Ford.  Because, other than leaving Morello in the van with Miss Rosa to see why the alarms were going off when Vee broke out, I can't think of a single bad move that guy has made.

Sure, if you compare it to something like bleach, DBZ, or naruto it's pretty good, but try comparing the pacing to kill la kill and it looks horrible, or the dialog and condensed information of psycho-pass and SAO just falls short.

name: t1_csw1xe2
author: takahashia16
body:
That is true Kirito and Asuna took on Death Scythe together but really Kirito's dual wielding and newfound skill was what won the fight. Klein is not on Kirito's level in terms of strength, power or even battle-healing. IIRC Kirito has maxed out most if not all of his battle stats whilst Klein has decent to high-range stats. Not much of what he has mentioned has been explained in the actual series. I can't like Kirito because he never struggles to progress, he always screams his way out of everything and has never lost a fight. He breaks out of paralysis and saves Asuna, how did that happen? He destroys a boss monster because he's pissed off that his guild was wiped? I thought this was a group game? None of this can be explained because the writer made that fatal mistake. Top 50 anime don't make these core mistakes.


Sticking together is the best bet for every character in a group-based MMO but apparently Kirito is above that. Another question is how is Asuna's stats roughly lower or the same as Kirito's when she has been with an actual guild doing far more dungeons than what Kirito seemed to be doing?

name: t1_ctltslz
author: strictfactor
body:
There are two issues with Deflategate that are at odds with each other:

1. There is a mountain of circumstantial evidence (but no direct evidence) suggesting that McNally deliberately deflated the Patriots footballs, and that Tom Brady knew about it.
2. The Patriots footballs were not deflated.

These points are diametrically opposed and mutually exclusive. Only one of those two things is true.

You detailed all the aspects of Point #1. It's an incredibly compelling story, filled with drama. There's a villain, there's a conspiracy, there's a fall from grace. It's awesome.

Point #2 is much more mundane. The Patriots balls were at 12.50 PSI before the game, they lost 1.01 PSI due to the cold weather, and that's that. It's a boring explanation.

It's science versus faith.

Point #1 has a lot of vague inferences that you can interpret however you like. You choose to interpret them to mean that footballs were deflated; I interpret them another way. Regardless of interpretation, the story doesn't have an "I prefer footballs below 12.5", or "I'll deflate the footballs", or security footage of deflation, or a confession, or any witnesses at all. There is no direct evidence. You can make your interpretations, and have faith that they're correct.

Point #2 is pure science. According to the Ideal Gas Law, the Patriots footballs should have lost between 0.98 and 1.18 PSI during the first half *if they were not deflated*. They lost 1.01 PSI. Therefore, they were not deflated.

I'm not trying to change your view, I just want to point out the difference between the groups, and make it clear which group you are in.

name: t3_1haww9
author: jonhull22
body:
I think, from the evidence released, that George Zimmerman is not guilty of murder. CMV

BY THE WAY: I'm not saying whether or not I think he did it... I don't know, you don't know. There's a trial for a reason, so please don't bring that shit in here. 

BUT: I've read several articles that say Zimmerman had gashes on his head, and a witness said that Trayvon Martin was on top of him in an MMA type position and that Zimmerman looked real beat up when witnesses first got there. If that's an eyewitness account then what else can they really go off of? There are other reports like that are similar from witnesses, so wouldn't a guilty verdict be really difficult to prove, or am I missing something.
